inlineContent.text: convenient way to access colors (and fonts
and style defaults) as well as the built-in theme.

abstract.text: Semantic color palette, including simple colors
plus “dark” / “light” definitions, with support
for built-in themes.
General background contrast, with negative
values providing lower contrast and positive
values providing higher contrast.
Degree to which highlighting should darken or
lighten the accent color depending on if
the scheme is light on dark or not.
Higher values provide more contrast between
foreground and background at the possible
expense of color purity.
Get the background color with a degree of luminance
(lightness/darkness) with optional inversion.
Default color/alpha to use with +.accentable items.
Degree of saturation for decorations like borders, etc.
Get the text color and whether it should be inverted
or affected by a control state.
Get the button text color with a degree of luminance
(lightness/darkness) with optional inversion.
Alpha used for decoration/border color when item is disabled
Alpha used for the item when disabled
Color to indicate a critical/potentially destructive action.
Degree of desaturation for disabled items.
Does this color scheme use predominantly
light backgrounds and dark text?
is a Swift framework for developing apps on iOS and iPadOS.
Color that is lighter than, and of sufficient
contrast to, the “dark” color.
Get the button decoration color with a degree of luminance
(lightness/darkness) with optional inversion.
Degree of luminance contrast that a deselected item
should have between background and foreground.
Get the background color and whether it should be inverted
or affected by a control state.
Set this to “true” if color scheme should
have darker text and decorations over top
of lighter backgrounds.
Get the button decoration color respecting if it should
be inverted explicitly or implicitly via palette setting.
In case display contrast is increased
(via Accessibility pane) this value determines
the value added to various color settings
in order to increase the contrast of the app.
Set this to “true” if color scheme should
have lighter text and decorations over top
of darker backgrounds.
Set this to “true” if buttons should “reverse out”
of their backgrounds.
Get the button background color with a degree of luminance
(lightness/darkness) with optional inversion.
Values used for overriding or augmenting color settings
based on accessibility preferences.
Color that is darker than, and of sufficient
contrast to, the “light” color.
Alpha used for text color when item is disabled
General foreground contrast, with negative
values providing lower contrast and positive
values providing higher contrast.
Degree of desaturation that a deselected item
should have between background and foreground.
Semantic color palette, including simple colors
plus “dark” / “light” definitions, with support
for built-in themes.
Simple color palette.
Alpha transparency of button background color.
Get the button background color respecting if it should
be inverted explicitly or implicitly via palette setting.
Get the text color and whether it should be inverted
or affected by a control state.
Color to indicate a passive/non-destructive action.
Does this color scheme use predominantly
dark backgrounds and light text?
Get the accent color with a degree of luminance
(lightness/darkness) relative to the background color.
Get the button text color respecting if it should
be inverted explicitly or implicitly via palette setting.
Get the text color with a degree of luminance
(lightness/darkness) with optional inversion.
Protocol to support style access and built-in themes.
Degree of contrast between foreground and
background for disabled items.
Get the accent color with a degree of luminance
(lightness/darkness) relative to the foreground color.
Alpha used for background color when item is disabled
Get the decoration color with a degree of luminance
(lightness/darkness) with optional inversion.
In the context of using implicit themes and live updates,
update the current color scheme.
